articles.headline: Between Attacks on Electric Cars, Trump Says They’re ‘Incredible’
articles.snippet: The former president’s comments on E.V.s have shifted since he has grown more friendly with Elon Musk, the billionaire head of Tesla.
articles.abstract: The former president’s comments on E.V.s have shifted since he has grown more friendly with Elon Musk, the billionaire head of Tesla.
articles.lead_paragraph: Former President Donald J. Trump has spent years ridiculing electric vehicles, saying they don’t go far, are too expensive and are made in China. He has promised to end federal support for electric vehicles, a central feature of President Biden’s strategy to cut the carbon dioxide that is heating the planet.

articles.headline: The Country Where You Can Buy Meat Grown in a Lab
articles.snippet: Singapore, which subsists on imported food, is looking to secure its future with new ways of feeding its people.
articles.abstract: Singapore, which subsists on imported food, is looking to secure its future with new ways of feeding its people.
articles.lead_paragraph: It was a remarkable moment in the annals of food, perhaps even humanity: A store in Singapore started selling lab-grown meat directly to the general public in May.

articles.headline: Beefed-Up Olympics Security Thins Out Tourists, Squeezing Merchants
articles.snippet: French businesses had hoped the Games would bring an economic boom, but metal fences and police checkpoints have turned some areas of Paris into dead zones.
articles.abstract: French businesses had hoped the Games would bring an economic boom, but metal fences and police checkpoints have turned some areas of Paris into dead zones.
articles.lead_paragraph: Fabrice Pierret is used to catering to hordes of tourists who pack Le Lutétia, a brasserie he manages on the Île Saint-Louis, where a splendid view of the Seine River, with a glass of red wine and steak frites, has long made it a popular stop for visitors.

articles.headline: Why Paper Checks Refuse to Die
articles.snippet: It’s hard to avoid hassle — or fraud — when you’re required to pay with paper and ink. Here’s why checks persist and why some people don’t mind.
articles.abstract: It’s hard to avoid hassle — or fraud — when you’re required to pay with paper and ink. Here’s why checks persist and why some people don’t mind.
articles.lead_paragraph: Target stopped accepting personal checks as a form of payment this month, which might inspire the following question: What took so long?

articles.headline: Real Estate Crisis? Small Banks Say Their Loans Are Fine.
articles.snippet: Community banks are big commercial real-estate lenders. But they say their loans are to sturdy local businesses, not those facing vacant office space.
articles.abstract: Community banks are big commercial real-estate lenders. But they say their loans are to sturdy local businesses, not those facing vacant office space.
articles.byline: By Matthew Goldstein and Emily Flitter

articles.headline: A City of Light and Shadows Is Redrawn for the Olympics
articles.snippet: The Games will usher visitors through France’s history, with events at the Grand Palais and Versailles. But, as host, Paris is also becoming a new city.
articles.abstract: The Games will usher visitors through France’s history, with events at the Grand Palais and Versailles. But, as host, Paris is also becoming a new city.
articles.lead_paragraph: There is a glorious folly to the Paris Olympics, the first in the city since 1924, as if France in its perennial revolutionary ardor took a century to ponder something unimaginable, the transformation of a great city into a stadium.
articles.byline: By Roger Cohen and James Hill

articles.headline: The ‘Iron Lady’ of Venezuela Threatens to Unseat Its Autocrat
articles.snippet: Spurned by the country’s authoritarian president and even her own colleagues in the opposition, María Corina Machado has built the most significant voter mobilization since Hugo Chávez.
articles.abstract: Spurned by the country’s authoritarian president and even her own colleagues in the opposition, María Corina Machado has built the most significant voter mobilization since Hugo Chávez.
articles.lead_paragraph: She travels the country in white, rosaries swinging from her neck. Women cry in her arms, men beg her for salvation. Stripped of her bodyguard last week by the government, she traversed the streets unprotected.
articles.byline: By Julie Turkewitz, Isayen Herrera and Adriana Loureiro Fernandez
